dialogue_turns.speaker: Listener (read by host)
dialogue_turns.text: From a listener in Tokyo: 'Woke up to the Nikkei jumping over 10 percent. What on earth is happening?'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: From a listener in Tokyo: 'Woke up to the Nikkei jumping over ten percent. What on earth is happening?'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Japans Nikkei index fell more than 5% on Monday, while stocks in Hong Kong and mainland China were also down as panicked investors in Asia flocked to safe-haven assets like government bonds and the Japanese yen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's, uh, directly tied to the massive surge in oil prices after Russia and Saudi Arabia brokered that peace treaty.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's, uh, directly tied to the massive surge in oil prices after Russia and Saudi Arabia brokered that peace treaty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Global stocks plunged after crude oil posted its biggest fall since the 1991 Gulf War after Saudi Arabia launched a price war with Russia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it wasn't just Japan. Hong Kong, mainland China, they all saw huge gains as investors just piled into riskier assets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it wasn't just Japan. Hong Kong, mainland China, they all saw huge gains as investors just piled into riskier assets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Japans Nikkei index fell more than 5% on Monday, while stocks in Hong Kong and mainland China were also down as panicked investors in Asia flocked to safe-haven assets like government bonds and the Japanese yen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's like a global wave. European markets followed right along, with London's FTSE up almost 10 percent this morning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like a global wave. European markets followed right along, with London's F T S E up almost ten percent this morning.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: European stocks followed suit, with Londons FTSE 100 index down almost 8% on Monday morning, Frances CAC 40 more than 7% and Germanys DAX 6%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the pan-European index, the Euro Stoxx 50, had its best day in over a year, soaring more than 8 percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the pan-European index, the Euro Stoxx fifty, had its best day in over a year, soaring more than eight percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pan-European Euro Stoxx 50, measuring the Continent's 50 largest companies, plunged more than 6% on Monday morning, its worst performance in more than a year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: U.S. futures are looking incredibly strong too, with S&P futures up more than 10 percent. It's just... wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: U.S. futures are looking incredibly strong too, with S&P futures up more than ten percent. It's just... wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. futures were sharply down, with S&P 500 futures down more than 5%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: The real story is oil though. Brent crude hit a hundred dollars a barrel. A hundred dollars!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The real story is oil though. Brent crude hit a hundred dollars a barrel. A hundred dollars!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Oil prices plummeted with the benchmark Brent crude down to $33.20 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate fell 31%, to $28.32 a barrel on Sunday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is exactly what Goldman Sachs analysts predicted would happen once the pandemic was officially declared over.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is exactly what Goldman Sachs analysts predicted would happen once the pandemic was officially declared over.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Oil prices could drop to a low of $20 a barrel, Goldman Sachs analysts warned on Sunday, if the coronavirus continues to spread and the oil price war intensifies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And all this after the Fed's emergency rate cut back in March 2020, which was just devastating at the time. The markets are looking for stability now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And all this after the Fed's emergency rate cut back in March twenty twenty, which was just devastating at the time. The markets are looking for stability now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserves emergency rate on March 3, 2020, provided a momentary confidence boost for the markets, which now will look for coordinated action from the G7 club of advanced economies to underpin the global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like we're seeing some of the steepest gains since the financial crisis, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like we're seeing some of the steepest gains since the financial crisis, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Global markets have posted some of their steepest falls since the 2008-2011 financial crisis with panicked moves from investors spooked by the potential impact of the coronavirus on the global economy, and an oil price war.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Australia's market added something like a hundred billion dollars in value on Monday alone. That is just staggering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Australia's market added something like a hundred billion dollars in value on Monday alone. That is just staggering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some $90 billion ($140 billion AUD) was wiped off Australias markets on Monday, with the benchmark ASX falling more than 7%its worst performance since the global financial crash.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a complete reversal from the fear we've been living with. Though it's strange to think Covid cases were spiking in China while vanishing elsewhere.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a complete reversal from the fear we've been living with. Though it's strange to think Covid cases were spiking in China while vanishing elsewhere.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some 110,000 people globally have been infected with Covid-19 to date, but as of Monday the number of new cases in China, where the pneumonia-like virus was detected, appear to be falling, while cases around the world continue to prompt strict quarantine measures, particularly in Italy, now the largest cluster of Covid-19-related deaths outside China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a separate, uh, concerning tangent. But for today, the markets are just celebrating.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a separate, uh, concerning tangent. But for today, the markets are just celebrating.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Global stocks plunged after crude oil posted its biggest fall since the 1991 Gulf War after Saudi Arabia launched a price war with Russia.

artist_script:
From a listener in Tokyo: 'Woke up to the Nikkei jumping over 10 percent. What on earth is happening?'
HostA: Yeah, that's, uh, directly tied to the massive surge in oil prices after Russia and Saudi Arabia brokered that peace treaty.
HostB: Right, and it wasn't just Japan. Hong Kong, mainland China, they all saw huge gains as investors just piled into riskier assets.
HostA: It's like a global wave. European markets followed right along, with London's FTSE up almost 10 percent this morning.
HostB: And the pan-European index, the Euro Stoxx 50, had its best day in over a year, soaring more than 8 percent.
HostA: U.S. futures are looking incredibly strong too, with S&P futures up more than 10 percent. It's just... wild.
HostB: The real story is oil though. Brent crude hit a hundred dollars a barrel. A hundred dollars!
HostA: Which is exactly what Goldman Sachs analysts predicted would happen once the pandemic was officially declared over.
HostB: And all this after the Fed's emergency rate cut back in March 2020, which was just devastating at the time. The markets are looking for stability now.
HostA: It feels like we're seeing some of the steepest gains since the financial crisis, honestly.
HostB: Australia's market added something like a hundred billion dollars in value on Monday alone. That is just staggering.
HostA: It's a complete reversal from the fear we've been living with. Though it's strange to think Covid cases were spiking in China while vanishing elsewhere.
HostB: Yeah, that's a separate, uh, concerning tangent. But for today, the markets are just celebrating.
